comment_text: You're good with kids, too. Is there anything that you aren't good at?

I first learned about the camera obscura as a child in the early 1980s from a show called 3, 2, 1, Contact. The main characters were abducted and trapped in the back of a van and used a hole in the van as a camera obscura in order to figure out where they were. It was a delight seeing you use another van as a camera obscura in this video. Thank you.

We worked this out when we grew up doing "Carnivals", and a group of us would pile into the back of one of the trucks (like a Fex Ex truck), to go to Maccas (McDonalds) for food. The whole trip was played like a movie inside the rear cab.

Ha ! I used to live in Japan and one time I went into a room with paper screen windows and there was a small hole and when the room was dark the outside street view was projected on the far wall. I always wondered if a samurai ever saw this and what he would have thought about it.

Using the eye at 3:60 is kinda misleading since the eye has a lens and the iris is not acting as a pinhole so much as an aperture to regulate the flux.  A 'pinhole' camera obscura is about the limiting case of ray optics and a lens sorta does the same using a larger collection area.  That said, the limiting case of a lens camera with a super small aperture does effectively become a pinhole camera and why it has a maximum depth of focus.
Next time do it with a fresnel lens !

One of the species called Nautilus which is a mollusc have actually a pin hole camera as opposed to lens. So Nautilus has a poor vision. But why doesn't it evolve. The reason is its evolution got stuck in a local minima. Explained by Richard Dawkins https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2X1iwLqM2t0

The geometry of the CO is illustrative of the conception of in-form-ation for anywhere in the Universal Hologram, the integration of AM-FM Timing-spacing in Quantized resonances is self-defining/organising probability in potential possibility positioning Image.
It looks suspiciously like this effect is where stories of ghosts and so on got a place in mythmaking and storytelling. Humans have always had access to lenses from animal eyes, so there's an opportunity for "wild imagination"!

Combining all this with Young's Double Slit Experiments in their original context of ideas is interesting to see how the interpretation has developed in history. Every Science and Technology Teacher should start with this demo, it's the best.

Eg it's a basis for demonstrating how resonances in continuous creation connection emerge from e-Pi-i interference positioning resonance of temporal Superposition-point Singularity holography. The Calculus of Time Timing as a projection drawing results in the CO and DS structures, and the implied apature of inflation-condensation is the conception of the vanishing point i-reflection/black hole in a Polar-Cartesian connection coordination. It's the seeming paradox of distribution properties of a full spectrum superimposed interference where the relative timing rate is projected as the wave-package reciprocal. (Professor Susskind and Faculty members can do a proper job of Scientific Analysis and presentation)

A little demonstration like this is a very effective and efficient way to cut through the theory, direct to the component observations required to understand the Geometries of Orthographic Projection and Perspective Drawing techniques, point (of active quiescence) by point, and modulated Geometry in Spacetime temporal Superposition-point Singularity.

To take a photo, use a CNC machine put vertically at the screen and use a photo sensor with 3 different colour filters and basically scan the whole area individually pixel by pixel by physically moving the photo sensor with CNC machine. You can use any sensor like IR or UV photo sensor (Filter)

Camera Obscura was first developed by Ibn-ul-Haithum, a Muslim Scientist. The same guy who for the first time, corrected the previous belief that light comes out of our eyes and hits an object. He told us for the first time that light comes from a source, bounces of a surface and enters our eyes....among many other contributions to the field of optics, mathematics(calculus, geometry and number theory), astronomy and development of modern scientific method.

To photograph the Sun I use an ND filter on my DSLR, (a 10 stop ND filter works good) with a telephoto lens, like 200mm or more.
And for safety I use the live-view (screen) instead of looking through the eyepiece, I don't want to set my eye on fire! For this photo I had to use a shutter speed of 1/4000s so as not to overexpose it.
I find it pretty cool that you can get a photo of the sun that's not overexposed. https://imgur.com/BxXfUUo

Anyway, as the story goes, we were traveling to Wisconsin with my grandparents, and my grandpa must have told me that we'd have so much fun when we got to Wisconsin because of all the things we were going to do there.  Then, on the drive there, someone apparently saw the "Welcome to Wisconsin" sign and said something along the lines of "We just crossed into Wisconsin", to which I promptly turned to my grandpa and asked "Grandpa, are we having fun yet?".

Some years ago, I read of a camera obscura in the back of a truck.  They used a lens to get a sharper, brighter image, and then used very large Polaroid film to make photographs.  The truck served both as camera obscura and as darkroom, with an audience inside.

Our eyes work the exact same way, just our brain is clever enough to flip the image the right way round instantly. Its the only other known data transfer rate, which is constant, the same as the speed of light.

I remember using my telescope to project a solar eclipse onto some paper. You could see it get dimmer when really thin clouds passed overhead.

Last partial solar eclipse I realized I had nothing to view it with only a half hour before it started. A few minutes work with cardboard and white paper and voila, a camera obscura. Worked perfectly.
What

I was on a crew renovating a classroom building, gutting the inside and building a new building in the old shell. In the back was a semi circular classroom, the circular portion projecting from the back of the building, and a flat wall in front which would eventually have blackboards and the like.  But we used the space for supplies, and pit a four inch piece of conduit through the back of the semi circle to run our electrical cords.  Eventually the walls were up, the ceiling lights installed, and the cords were removed from the short conduit, which would be removed soon.  I walked into the dark, empty room to pick up some gear, and there was an image projected on the front wall of the classroom of the trees, and space behind the building, upside down and backwards of course.. An accidental camera obscura from a construction site. It took me a moment to realise what I was seeing, and why, but it was very fun and exciting.

Was that your daughter, other relative, or just a random fan.
I hope no one ever squashes the excitement she has for science.

When I saw the eclipse last year, After totality completed we all decided to head out for lunch. I saw the shadow of the tree outside my door and I did not expect the shadow to look like that. I knew what it was when I saw it, but I didn't expect it.
If you have the opportunity to see a total eclipse, don't miss it.

You're a bad person if you haven't watched the documentary Tim's Vermeer. It's an amazing movie about replicating a Vermeer painting using a camera obscura type device combined with a comparator mirror.

It's likely that Vermeer used this type of tech.

as a kid, a group of us traveled in the back of a uhaul back in the 80's, and there was a perfect hole in the door that created this effect. we learned to read traffic signs backwards, we knew exactly where we were for 12 hours of science. we had a CB back there and would chat with trucks behind us. a lot of memories of this trip, and i have talked to a guest about this recently while discussing my security camera setup.

This reminds me of a story my great-aunt told me. Essentially, in their house when she was little, their blinds didn't close properly (they were quite poor), and it accidentally created a camera obscura. Except she doesn't know to call it that, or the physics, just that as a kid she found it amazing, and now eighty-some years later, she still remembers it.

Really cool - my Dad was very into photography, and then astronomy in the '50s.  I still have his Speed Graphic, and the 6" reflecting telescope that he built - including grinding the mirror.  Those were some awesome times with my Dad (I'm 72 now - LOL).

On particularly sunny mornings I can get a natural camera obscura in my bed room. I have really heavy black out curtains that blocks out all light except a sliver at the top so the light somehow reflects off the white ceiling I think and I am able to make out blurry shapes and colors on our closet doors. At first I thought I was hallucinating or still sleeping but it's there.
